text: {"grade": 1, "reasoning": "The criterion requires the response to advise that the defence will fail if the client's use of force was not to avert an imminent or immediately apprehended attack. Section 4.2, titled 'Imminence,' explicitly addresses this, stating that self-defence does not justify pre-emptive strikes against anticipated future threats and citing *R v Beckford* which confirms the force must be reasonable in the circumstances as the defendant believed them to be. Furthermore, Section 4.3 on 'Necessity' discusses that the defendant must have believed force was necessary, linking directly to the requirement of an immediate threat.", "criterion_id": "74ca3b09-c13e-4143-b0da-ede48e93caee"}
